newsitem.title: INDIA: India stocks end lower as foreign funds stay quiet.
newsitem.headline: India stocks end lower as foreign funds stay quiet.

text.p: ** (1230 GMT) - Indian bourses close with small losses
** Bombay's benchmark index closes 3.62 pts lower at
3,940.99, off 4,029.56--intra-day high
** Fresh foreign fund buying fails to materialise as
traders see sharp volatility affecting buy orders
** National Stock Exchange 50-stock index gains 15.60
points, or 1.39 pct, to 1,132.90 at start of new account
** Delhi index falls 9.65 pts to 827.40, Calcutta 4.70 pts
to 474.65 and Madras 26.67 pts to 3,690.26
Major Indian bourses closed slightly lower on Wednesday as buying by foreign funds failed to materialise in a day of volatile trade, dealers said.
"There is going to be some profit-taking at these levels, around 4,000. This is really healthy for the market," said Basant Agarwal, head of equities at JM Share & Stock Brokers.

"The reaction gives a chance for general investors to enter the market," Agarwal said. Stocks at the National Stock Exchange however, ended higher on fresh position building by operators at the start of the weekly account.
At the Bombay bourse, many pivotals including ACC, BHEL, Sterlite and Hindalco hit their 25 percent ceiling on price increases in a week, dealers said.
"The market is consolidating gains," said Dinesh Khemlani, dealer at Bombay brokerage Khandwala Finance Ltd. "Most shares are at their peak and there's no scope for further rise."
The sharp price fluctuations in blue chip stocks kept foreign funds on the sidelines, thus offsetting market hopes of fund demand fuelling a rally, dealers said.
"They (foreign funds) are very selective buyers and have not jumped in the market," JM's Agarwal said.

In the 1997/98 (April-March) budget presented to Parliament last week, Finance Minister P. Chidambaram slashed corporate and personal taxes, raised foreign portfolio limit in Indian firms and lowered import duties on a wide range of goods.
The new reforms asserted India's commitment to continued economic liberalisation begun in 1991 and helped improve confidence among foreign investors, analysts said.
In morning trade, the benchmark BSE 30-share index on Wednesday crossed an eight month high of 4,007.91 reached last week at 4,029.56, but lost way and ended at 3,939.0.
-- Anshuman Daga, Bombay equities desk +91-22-265 9000
